bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, August 27, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg sends Hench copies of correspondence with Carlos E. Finlay. He discusses Cubans' attitudes toward the work of Carlos J. Finlay and the possibility of a "Cuban version" of the Cornwell painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, August 27, 1941
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
August 27, 1941
Dear Dr. Hench,
div1.p:
Enclosed find copy of a letter from Dr. Finlay re-
ceived this morning, along with a copy of my reply and the printed
copy of the speech to which his letter refers.

It seems, according to his letter, that he does appre-
ciate the fact that in bringing Dr. Finlay into the picture along with
the Yellow Fever Board, we have made a step in the right direction as
far as he is concerned. As I see the controversy mentioned in the
speech read by Dr. Cepero it would seem that the greatest difficulty
in the minds of the Cubans is the fact that we did not accept the so-
called experiments of Dr. Finlay as proving anything. This attitude
on the part of Americans is identical with the attitude taken by Dr.
Finlay's Cuban associates at the time the experiments were done. As
you have said many times, it seems a shame that Finlay should appear
to be somewhat ridiculous as a result of the insistence of his country-
men in attempting to make these early experiments prove something.
When the present generation dies off perhaps the Cubans will be more
ready to accept a less biased point of view.

As to the second painting on yellow fever which I men-
tioned to Dr. Finlay, it is only a vague hope that prompted me to make
this statement in my letter to him. If our Export Department puts
enough pressure on the management it is possible that in a few years
we could have the so-called Cuban version as well. It would undoubtedly
go over very well down there.

I am glad that you liked the framed sketch of Reed and
hope that the framed proofs of “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” arrive in
a few days.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
